articles.headline: Divided Over Abortion, but Joining Forces for Women’s Workplace Rights
articles.snippet: Unlikely allies have worked together on issues facing pregnant women and new mothers in states that are tightening abortion restrictions.
articles.abstract: Unlikely allies have worked together on issues facing pregnant women and new mothers in states that are tightening abortion restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When South Carolina passed a law last year to provide pregnant workers and new mothers with more protections in the workplace, it was driven by an unlikely alliance: supporters of abortion rights working alongside religious groups that oppose them.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Approves Facebook Fine of About $5 Billion
articles.snippet: If approved by the Justice Department, the settlement would be the biggest fine levied by the federal government against a technology company.
articles.abstract: If approved by the Justice Department, the settlement would be the biggest fine levied by the federal government against a technology company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has approved a fine of roughly $5 billion against Facebook for mishandling users’ personal information, according to three people briefed on the vote, in what would be a landmark settlement that signals a newly aggressive stance by regulators toward the country’s most powerful technology companies.

articles.headline: Katrina on Its Mind, New Orleans Keeps an Anxious Eye on Tropical Storm Barry
articles.snippet: The trauma of levee failures loomed large as residents scrambled to stock food, fill sandbags and pump their cars with gas.
articles.abstract: The trauma of levee failures loomed large as residents scrambled to stock food, fill sandbags and pump their cars with gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Water can come at you from multiple angles in a city surrounded by it. Joseph Thomas, 51, remembers how it came into his neighborhood last time.
articles.byline: By Emily Lane, Beau Evans and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: Facial Recognition Tech Is Growing Stronger, Thanks to Your Face
articles.snippet: Large databases, built with images from social networks and dating services, contain millions of pictures of people’s faces. Some are shared worldwide.
articles.abstract: Large databases, built with images from social networks and dating services, contain millions of pictures of people’s faces. Some are shared worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Dozens of databases of people’s faces are being compiled without their knowledge by companies and researchers, with many of the images then being shared around the world, in what has become a vast ecosystem fueling the spread of facial recognition technology.

articles.headline: Facebook Dodged a Bullet From the F.T.C. It Faces Many More.
articles.snippet: The social network may have escaped restrictions and financial bruising with the F.T.C.’s settlement, but its pain is just beginning around the world.
articles.abstract: The social network may have escaped restrictions and financial bruising with the F.T.C.’s settlement, but its pain is just beginning around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After Facebook was hit on Friday with a fine of around $5 billion for privacy violations, critics immediately said it escaped largely unscathed: The settlement neither bruised its bottom line nor severely restricted its ability to collect people’s data.

articles.headline: Pete Buttigieg’s Life in the Closet
articles.snippet: And why it took him until he was 33 to come out.
articles.abstract: And why it took him until he was 33 to come out.
articles.lead_paragraph: The closet that Pete Buttigieg built for himself in the late 1990s and 2000s was a lot like the ones that other gay men of his age and ambition hid inside. He dated women, deepened his voice and furtively looked at MySpace and Friendster profiles of guys who had come out — all while wondering when it might be safe for him to do so too.

articles.headline: Trump Tells Congresswomen to ‘Go Back’ to the Countries They Came From
articles.snippet: The attack, which was widely established as a racist trope, appeared to be meant for four progressive freshmen who have clashed with Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Only one was born outside the United States.
articles.abstract: The attack, which was widely established as a racist trope, appeared to be meant for four progressive freshmen who have clashed with Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Only one was born outside the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Sunday that a group of four minority congresswomen feuding with Speaker Nancy Pelosi should “go back” to the countries they came from rather than “loudly and viciously telling the people of the United States” how to run the government.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: A Hit Podcast Finds ‘True Crime’ in the Justice System
articles.snippet: Facts brought to light by “In the Dark,” led by the reporter Madeleine Baran and the producer Samara Freemark, made their way to the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Facts brought to light by “In the Dark,” led by the reporter Madeleine Baran and the producer Samara Freemark, made their way to the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — On a fall day in 2015, Madeleine Baran and Samara Freemark went for a walk through the extensive skyway that threads through the buildings of downtown St. Paul.

articles.headline: Fighting Big Tech Makes for Some Uncomfortable Bedfellows
articles.snippet: Conservatives are showing up at largely liberal conferences to call for breaking up Facebook and Google. Liberals are going on conservative TV shows to do the same. It’s awkward.
articles.abstract: Conservatives are showing up at largely liberal conferences to call for breaking up Facebook and Google. Liberals are going on conservative TV shows to do the same. It’s awkward.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was not a given that Steve Hilton, the conservative Fox News host, and Tim Wu, a Columbia University law professor who worked in the Obama White House, would get along.

articles.headline: ‘The Town Hall of Hollywood.’ Welcome to the Netflix Lobby.
articles.snippet: Every day an entertainment’s who’s who passes through the 4,780-square-foot “creative gateway” — complete with 80-foot video screen — hoping for a piece of the billions Netflix is spending on content.
articles.abstract: Every day an entertainment’s who’s who passes through the 4,780-square-foot “creative gateway” — complete with 80-foot video screen — hoping for a piece of the billions Netflix is spending on content.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dolly Parton recently held court there, big wig and all. Leonardo DiCaprio and John Kerry arrived at the same time last month. Cindy Crawford on the left, David Letterman on the right. And isn’t that Beyoncé by the espresso bar?

articles.headline: Trump Fans the Flames of a Racial Fire
articles.snippet: While other presidents have found ways to appeal to the resentments of white Americans with subtle and not-so-subtle appeals, none of them in modern times have done so as overtly as this one.
articles.abstract: While other presidents have found ways to appeal to the resentments of white Americans with subtle and not-so-subtle appeals, none of them in modern times have done so as overtly as this one.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump woke up on Sunday morning, gazed out at the nation he leads, saw the dry kindling of race relations and decided to throw a match on it. It was not the first time, nor is it likely to be the last. He has a pretty large carton of matches and a ready supply of kerosene.

articles.headline: China’s Economic Growth Hits 27-Year Low as Trade War Stings
articles.snippet: Rising tariffs on Chinese goods sold to the U.S. are taking an increasing toll, but the country is also suffering from cracks in its financial system.
articles.abstract: Rising tariffs on Chinese goods sold to the U.S. are taking an increasing toll, but the country is also suffering from cracks in its financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s growth fell to its slowest pace in nearly three decades, officials disclosed on Monday, as a resurgence of trade tensions with the United States and lingering financial problems take an increasing toll on one of the world’s most vital economic engines.

articles.headline: How Joe Biden Became the Democrats’ Anti-Busing Crusader
articles.snippet: With a school desegregation lawsuit roiling Delaware in the 1970s, Mr. Biden led an effort in the Senate to end court-ordered busing.
articles.abstract: With a school desegregation lawsuit roiling Delaware in the 1970s, Mr. Biden led an effort in the Senate to end court-ordered busing.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Del. — In July 1974, with a federal court in Delaware on the verge of ordering busing to integrate Wilmington’s overwhelmingly black public schools, Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived at a school auditorium in this predominantly white suburb to find himself the target of a political ambush.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: And Then There Was One: Three People Lived in This Village Until Two Were Murdered.
articles.snippet: Thirty years ago, 200 people lived in the Moldovan village of Dobrusa. But most have since left or died. After a twin killing in February, there’s only one survivor still standing.
articles.abstract: Thirty years ago, 200 people lived in the Moldovan village of Dobrusa. But most have since left or died. After a twin killing in February, there’s only one survivor still standing.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOBRUSA, Moldova — Thirty years ago, the village of Dobrusa had about 200 residents. At the start of this year, it had just three.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: Japan Cites ‘National Security’ in Free Trade Crackdown. Sound Familiar?
articles.snippet: Tokyo has moved to limit exports of chemicals to big South Korean chip makers like Samsung, citing vague threats to Japan’s security. Seoul says a political dispute is the real reason for the move.
articles.abstract: Tokyo has moved to limit exports of chemicals to big South Korean chip makers like Samsung, citing vague threats to Japan’s security. Seoul says a political dispute is the real reason for the move.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, before an audience of world leaders, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan forcefully defended the global trade order that President Trump has so dramatically fractured.

articles.headline: After Trump Accuses Four Democratic Congresswomen of Hating U.S., They Fire Back
articles.snippet: President Trump amplified his attacks against the lawmakers, and they responded by charging that he was pressing the agenda of white nationalists from the White House.
articles.abstract: President Trump amplified his attacks against the lawmakers, and they responded by charging that he was pressing the agenda of white nationalists from the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, under fire for comments that even members of his own party called racist, amplified his attacks on four Democratic congresswomen of color on Monday, saying that they hated America and that one of the first two Muslim women elected to Congress sympathized with Al Qaeda.

articles.headline: Most Migrants at Border With Mexico Would Be Denied Asylum Protections Under New Trump Rule
articles.snippet: The rule, which goes into effect Tuesday, denies protections to migrants who failed to apply for asylum in the first country they passed through on their way to the United States’ southwestern border.
articles.abstract: The rule, which goes into effect Tuesday, denies protections to migrants who failed to apply for asylum in the first country they passed through on their way to the United States’ southwestern border.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before a surge of migrants from Central America overwhelmed the southwestern border, the Trump administration was already waging a broad assault on the rules determining who can seek asylum in the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
